AT-descriptions.AT-description: The 'Mangroves of Hawaii' is a regional ecosystem subgroup (level 4 unit of the IUCN Global Ecosystem Typology) that includes intertidal forest and shrublands of the marine ecoregions of Hawaii (Hawaii province). The biota is characterised by 0 species of true mangroves and other key plant taxa that provide structure and resources for approx. 0 mangove-associated taxa. Mangroves in this subgroup have a mapped extent of at least ... km2 in ... countries and are predominantly ... and .... They are threatened by conversion for urban and tourism development, agriculture and aquaculture, and by increases in frequency of tropical storms.

Biota-Summaries.Biota-Summary: The biota of 'Mangroves of Hawaii' is characterised by the presence of 0 true mangrove and other key plant species. The range maps of overlap with most of the distribution of this unit. There are 00 species that have been associated with mangrove habitats in the Red List of Threatened Species database and that have natural history collection records or observations within the distribution of this unit (GBIF 2021).

Distribution-Summaries.Distribution-Summary: The 'Mangroves of Hawaii' includes intertidal forest and shrublands of the marine ecoregions of Hawaii (Hawaii province), that extent across 3 countries and territories in the regions of North America, East Asia & Pacific.
